definition: A change or addition to a constitution, law, or bill.
A proposed law presented to a legislature for consideration.
A meeting of supporters or members of a specific political party or movement.
A voting member of a community or organization with the power to elect representatives.
A tactic used in the Senate to delay or prevent a vote on a bill by extending debate.
The main election where voters choose between candidates from different parties.
The practice of drawing electoral district boundaries to favor one party or group.
The lower chamber of the U.S. Congress, with members serving two-year terms representing districts.
An election where voters choose candidates to represent their party in the general election.
The upper chamber of the U.S. Congress, with two senators from each state serving six-year terms.
